generation

Class MazeBuilderEller

  • java.lang.Object
    • generation.MazeBuilder
      • generation.MazeBuilderEller
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class MazeBuilderEller
extends generation.MazeBuilder
implements java.lang.Runnable
    This class has the responsibility to create a maze of given dimensions (width, height) together with a solution based on a distance matrix. The MazeBuilder implements Runnable such that it can be run a separate thread. The MazeFactory has a MazeBuilder and handles the thread management. The maze is built with Eller's algorithm. Every cell begins as its own set, and sets expand by joining with other adjoining sets. Ultimately every cell in the maze is merged into one all-containing set.
    Author:
    Elijah Mas

    • Method Detail

      • retrieve_cells

        protected int[][] retrieve_cells()

      • generatePathways

        protected void generatePathways()

        Overrides MazeBuilder.generatePathways(); generates pathways into maze via wall removal by way of Eller's algorithm. Eller's algorithm follows these steps:

        1. Initialize every cell in the maze:
          • to be in its own set, if not in a room
          • if in a room, in the same set with other cells in the room
          The first row is the current row.
        2. Randomly merge different sets in the current row by removing walls between them; set cell values to be the same when two sets merge.
        3. Randomly connect sets in the current row with the next row. This involves joining cells with vertical neighbors and merging sets. Each set in the current row must have at least one vertical connection to the new row.
        4. Repeat steps 2-3 for succesive rows until the penultimate and last row are connected.
        5. Finally, merge all sets in the last row by removing only those walls which sit between cells of distinct sets.
        One extra step is added: on the unlikely chance that there is still a closed room after the algorithm finishes, we check for rooms, and if one is found, we randomly remove one or two walls from its enclosing.

        Overrides:
        generatePathways in class generation.MazeBuilder

      • checkNoRooms

        java.util.HashSet<java.lang.Integer> checkNoRooms()

      • mergeSets

        private void mergeSets(int[] firstCoordinate,
                       int[] secondCoordinate)

        Given two sets with reference to coordinates in this.cells, combine the two sets by transferring all coordinates to one of the two sets and deleting the other set from cellSets. Each set is identified by an integer; in most cases, the set that is kept is that which has the lower value of the two. The exception is if one set is a room; in that case, room cells are added to the set of the other cell, and the room set is removed.

        This method does NOT check to see if the merge is valid, NOR does it perform wallboard removal--these must be handled externally.

        Parameters:
        firstCoordinate - location of one cell
        secondCoordinate - location of other cell

      • wallRemovalFromRow

        private void wallRemovalFromRow(int rowIndex)

        Randomly remove vertical wallboards from floorplan in a row, predicated upon:

        • The walls must sit between cells of different sets
        • The walls must not be marked as borders

        There are different ways to randomize wall removal. Two options are:

        • randomly decide how many walls to remove ahead of time, and randomly remove walls until that number is reached.
        • visit each wall, and randomly decide (with some fixed probability) to remove or keep that wall.

        This method makes use of the second approach.

        Parameters:
        rowIndex - the index of the row

      • link_CurrentRow_NewRow

        void link_CurrentRow_NewRow(int currentRowIndex)

        Extend the sets of the current row into the following row, By randomly selecting locations where cells will merge vertically. The following row is that in the positive x direction.

        We again have ways to randomize this. Repeating the options from before:

        • randomly decide how many cells to join ahead of time, and randomly do so until that number is reached.
        • visit each cell, and randomly decide (with some fixed probability) to join the cell or leave it alone.

        This time we take a variant of the first approach: the number we arrive at is an upper bound on how many links we might establish. There is a reason for taking this approach: we must perform at least one extension for each set, and the semantics of performing this are simpler in the first approach.
        Parameters:
        currentRowIndex - index of the current row

      • handleLastRow

        void handleLastRow()
        Perform the final step of Eller's algorithm: remove all walls between cells of distinct sets last row.

      • retreiveArbitrarySetValue

        private java.lang.Object retreiveArbitrarySetValue(java.util.Set s,
                                                   int iters)

        Pull an arbitrary value from a given set.

        Worded as "arbitrary" not "random" because random number generation is not invoked within this method: the method loops through the input set's iterator and pulls the object obtained at iteration iters (iterations start at 0). By default, the single-argument wrapper method sets iters=0.

        "arbitrary" because the order of elements in general, the Set interface does not guarantee any particular ordering of elements.

        Random number generation can be incorporated by passing a random integer generated elsewhere to the iters parameter.

        Parameters:
        s - the set of objects
        iters - the position in the iteration at which to return
        Returns:
        an object from the set

      • getArbitraryValueFromSet

        private java.lang.Object getArbitraryValueFromSet(java.util.Set s)

        Parameters:

      • getCellRoomNeighbors

        private java.util.HashSet<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>> getCellRoomNeighbors(java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> cell)
        Return all the neighbors of a cell that are in the same room as the cell. This method will not be called before walls are removed, so it can use the property that rooms are initialized with walls bordering the room and no walls inside the room to select cell neighbors.
        Parameters:
        cell - a cell, which must be in a room.
        Returns:
        the neighbors of this cell inside the cell's room

      • getRoomNeighborsOfCells

        java.util.HashSet<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>> getRoomNeighborsOfCells(java.util.Set<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>> cells)
        Given a set of cells in a room, return a set all cells that are neighbors of these cells. The set will contain only unique cells, but this set may overlap with the original set of cells passed in as an argument, if any cells in that set were neighbors of each other.
        Parameters:
        cells - a set of cells
        Returns:
        the set containing all neighbors of these cells

      • initializeCells

        void initializeCells()
        Initialize the set values in the cells array so that
        • every cell not in a room belongs to its own set;
